page.title: 01ARABLE FIELDS OF S.W SUFFOLK
page.content: This block chiefly consists of gently undulating arable fields with a few parcels of old woodland and two areas of parkland. The narrow twisty roads have had their accompanying hedges replaced by standard trees and awkward field corners have been wooded. Most of the original small farms have been aquired by one company and the buildings resold for private accommodation. The area is pockmarked with partially silted small ponds, an irrigation reservoir and a small lake and is bisected by the tiny river Brett. The only local employment is on the farms or domestic work, most other workers have to commute to surrounding towns by car as the only buses run on Wednesday and Saturday and then only twice a day to Bury St. Edmunds. Children have to bus to schools outside the area, but Brettenham has a
